column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0001] The present invention relates to the field of assemblies for fastening wear members to support structures, for example, ground engaging teeth to adaptors of powered equipment.
#Text=[0002] Many types of excavating equipment utilize replaceable ground-engaging teeth.
#Text=These teeth erode through use and are frequently replaced.
#Text=Depending on the conditions, a given support structure or adaptor would be re-equipped with from 5 to 30 teeth to maintain a sharp penetrating edge during excavation.
#Text=The ease of replacement of the teeth is important because it minimizes the amount of wasted throw-away material and also minimizes the downtime of the tool.
#Text=[0003] The prior art assemblies used to attach a tooth to the adaptor consist mainly of two designs, the wedge design and the pin design.
#Text=In the wedge design, the tooth is joined to the adaptor by wedges which are hammered into corresponding slots in the tooth and the adaptor.
#Text=This design has the disadvantage that the wedges would often become dislodged during use of the excavating equipment.
#Text=To prevent this problem, the wedge was tack-welded in place.
#Text=However, removal of the wedges became difficult and time consuming.
#Text=It also required the drag-line bucket, for example, to be turned on its front end to gain access to the wedges.
#Text=Further, during removal, the wedges had a tendency to shatter or break causing pieces to jam in the slots and posed a serious safety hazard to workers.
#Text=Wedge designs are shown, for example, in U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=[0004] Pin assemblies are shown in U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=This patent discloses a threaded pin and insert assembly for securing a tooth onto the adaptor.
#Text=The threaded insert is placed into the adaptor pin opening.
#Text=The tooth is placed over the adaptor.
#Text=A lock washer is concentrically placed over the pin opening on the tooth.
#Text=The pin is then screwed into the insert.
#Text=This assembly had the disadvantage of being cumbersome and complex in design making it difficult to use and increasing the time needed to replace the tooth.
#Text=As well, the pin has a tendency to loosen from the insert while the tooth is in use.
#Text=Another pin assembly is shown in U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 3,410,010 which discloses a dipper tooth having a detent and key assembly inserted into a passage in the tooth and adaptor.
#Text=This assembly suffers from the drawback that the key would often fall out of the passage during use of the tooth allowing the tooth to fall off the adaptor.

#Text=[0005] These wedge and pin assemblies were used not only for attaching ground-engaging teeth to adaptors on excavating equipment but also for attaching other types of wear members to support structures such as for example, attaching a protective lip shroud to a bucket lip.
